## Cleaning income variable RULES
# 1. When a participant provided a range (90000-10000) to their income, the median value of the range was used
# 2. When a participant provided a currency multiplier (i.e Lakh, crore, mil, jut), it was converted to the respective numerical value
# 3. When a participant provided a currency symbol that was different to their own, the currency was converted to their home currency using respective up-to-date conversion rates
# 4. When a participant provided an ambigious currency symbol, home currency was used (researchers fact checked the respective income using average income reporting per country)
# 5. When a participant provided written word for the amount of their income, it was converted to its respective numerical value (When in English)
# 6. When a pariticpant provided written word in a language other then english, it was translated using multiple translation software (for reliability) and then recoded to its numerical value
# 7. When a participant provided + or - at the end of their income, the value was recoded as the numerical value the particpant provided at the time of data collection
# 8. When a participant described their income as approximate / about, the value was recoded as the numerical value the pariticpant provided at the time of data collection
# 9. When a participant reported their income as unsure / not sure, that was recoded as NA
# 10 When a participant reported that they had no income (english), that was recoded as 0
# 11 When a participant reported in a foreign language they had no income, that was translated using multiple foreign language translation programs for reliability then recoded as 0
# 12 When a participant written word with a numerical value, the written word was stripped from the participants response
# 13 When a participant reported their income using k to describe thousands (i.e 10k), it was recoded as 10000
# 14 When a participant used symbols that had no numerical information (i.e # or ~) in conjunction with their income, that symbol was stripped from the response
# 15 Both . and , were stripped in accordance with cultural specific code that targeted within country income reporting (i.e 12,00,00 = 120000 or 1.500,00 = 1500 or 1,500.00 = 1500)
# 16 When a participant reported their respective countries income symbol or code with their numerical income, those codes and symbols were stripped from within that countries responses
# 17 When a participant reported their income in a mathmatical formula (i.e 3000 x 12), their respective income was calculated for that specific case
# 18 When a participant left spaces in their income, those spaces were stripped (i.e 12 000 = 12000)
# 19 When a participant provided exact change to their income, their value was rounded up or down to the nearest dollar unit (1200.75 = 1201 or 1200.20 = 1200)

## Creating new annual income variable based upon income 1 - 4
## PIPE OPERATOR = SHIFT + CTRL + M (AND THEN)
```{r}
INCOMECLEAN$Total_Income = NA
INCOMECLEAN$Total_Income <- as.numeric(INCOMECLEAN$Total_Income)

INCOMECLEAN <- INCOMECLEAN %>% mutate(
  Total_Income =
    dplyr::coalesce(
      Income_4, 12 * Income_3, 52 * Income_2,
      365 * Income_1
    )
)

```

```{r}

annual_inc  <- function(Income_1, Income_2, Income_3, Income_4){
  if (is.na(Income_1) == FALSE) Income_1*365
  else if (is.na(Income_2) == FALSE) Income_2*52
  else if (is.na(Income_3) == FALSE) Income_3*12
  else if (is.na(Income_4) == FALSE) Income_4
  else NA}

INCOMECLEAN$annual_inc = mapply(FUN = annual_inc, INCOMECLEAN$Income_1, INCOMECLEAN$Income_2, INCOMECLEAN$Income_3, INCOMECLEAN$Income_4)
```
